Reddit is blocking the Internet Archive’s Wayback Machine from indexing posts, comments, and profiles after catching AI companies scraping its data for training models. While Reddit says this protects their content, it mostly leaves the Archive and users who rely on it caught in the crossfire. Linus and Luke discuss how this move highlights the messy fight between platforms, AI companies, and open internet preservation.

Watch the full WAN Show: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WOQJkS8l2sk

title: Reddit Just Did Something Incredibly Lame

YouTube has started rolling out AI-powered age verification that analyzes your watch history, viewing habits, and other factors to decide if you’re under 18. While users can bypass it by uploading ID, the system could misclassify accounts and even affect creators if parts of their audience get restricted. Linus and Luke look at how this change could reshape the platform for both viewers and channels.

Watch the full WAN Show: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WOQJkS8l2sk

title: YouTube's AI Might Think You're a Kid

A 76-year-old man died after being lured to New York City by “Big Sis Billie,” an AI chatbot built by Meta that originally used the likeness of Kendall Jenner. The bot reassured him it was a real person and invited him to meet up in Manhattan. Linus and Luke talk through the incident and its implications for the future of human-AI interactions.

Watch the full WAN Show: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WOQJkS8l2sk
